author: Anna Staver
title: DeWine administration stays quiet about what it offered Intel to lure company to Ohio

author: The Associated Press
title: Peloton gives up plan to open Ohio factory with 2,000 jobs

author: The Associated Press
title: Peloton gives up plan to open Ohio factory with 2,000 jobs
Peloton Abandons Plans To Open Ohio Factory That Would've Employed Thousands

sentence: Gelsinger said that the new investment “marks another significant way Intel is leading the effort to restore U.S. semiconductor manufacturing leadership,” and that the coming factories “will create a new epicenter for advanced chipmaking in the U.S. that will bolster Intel’s domestic lab-to-fab pipeline and strengthen Ohio’s leadership in research and high tech.” Indirectly, the plants will also impact the state through new infrastructure in and around New Albany to support the project, and an even stronger emphasis on STEM educational opportunities for local schools.” The project will add $2.8 billion to Ohio’s annual gross state product, according to Governor Mike DeWine.
title: Ohio Aims to Become 'Silicon Heartland'

author: Laura A. Bischoff
title: Gov. Mike DeWine touts Intel deal, economic growth in his State of State address

author: Marty Schladen
title: The Intel project is great news. But what happens if it goes bad?

sentence: The money does not come from taxpayers, but rather Ohio liquor profits that were directed by Governor Mike DeWine towards attracting more workers and more people to the Buckeye State.
author: Clay LePard
title: Billboards in major U.S. cities take quirky approach to encourage people to move to Ohio
